div.p: 1. VI.30. Tuesday.

Mr Noah Curtis called to inform me that his Son Samuel did not incline to take my house which he now occupies, for the whole year from the first of April next; he expects to enter his own new house, which he is about to build, on the first of September, and in the mean time, if I should lease my house from the first of April, he hopes to make his arrangement with my tenant so that he may remain in my house until his own will be ready for him— Faxon came with a blacksmith’s Account, and Spear with his
last Load of wood— Mr and Mrs John Greenleaf and Mr and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf dined and spent part of the Evening with us— My time was engaged in preparations for my departure and for leaving the house here in the charge of Mr and Mrs Farrar— My writing fell in arrear; but I finished reading the second Volume of Grahame’s History of the rise and progress of the United States— In proportion to the progress I have made in the reading of this Book, has the satisfaction which it gave me increased. It is incomparably the best History of the Settlements of the British on the Continent of America that has ever been published— The only one that does justice to the puritan Settlers of New-England. It strips William Penn of his borrowed plumage; leaving him all that properly belongs to him, and treating his reputation with the utmost tenderness and delicacy. This work has supplied a great desideratum of American History and Literature. It has relieved me from a burden of obligation which I felt of exhibiting the same picture, and has performed the task better than I could have done— To this book if I have life and health, I hope hereafter to return.
2— V. Wednesday. Departure from home— Boston.

Mary Foster left us and returned home in the Stage— Louisa Smith remains to close the house to-morrow, and then goes to spend the winter with her Sister Foster at Boston. I told W. C. Greenleaf that if he should be disengaged, on my purposed return here next Spring, I should be glad to have his assistance again to reside with me— My brother came and passed the forenoon, and dined with me— At four in the afternoon I left my home at Quincy, and went first to Mr Lemuel Bracket’s, where I executed and acknowledged before him, the Deed in Trust of the Tomb of my father and mother under the Meeting House, of the Pews N. 1. and 2. and of the Marble Monument over them, to the Supervisors of the Adams Temple and School-fund— They had passed a vote agreeing to accept the donation upon the Conditions, prescribed in my draught of the deed— I left the Deed itself with Mr Bracket who promised to deliver it to Mr Thomas Greenleaf the President or to my brother the Secretary of the Supervisors— After completing this business I came into Boston with John Thomas and with Isaac Farrar who was to have taken the Horses and Carriage back to Quincy— But disagreeing with Farrar about the terms of keeping the Horses through the Winter, I determined to leave them with my Son Charles, to be disposed of by him— I spent the Evening with my Son Charles; and sent to engage two Seats in the Commercial Line of Stages to Providence, to depart at five O’Clock to-morrow Morning— Dr George Parkman came and spent part of the Evening with us.
3— IV:30— Thursday— Providence— Steam-boat President— Captain Bunker.

Soon after the Clock struck four I was roused by the Stageman, and took my Seat in the Carriage— The driver went to two other houses and took in two Passengers, entire Strangers to me. We rode about two hours in the dark, and reached Dedham about Sunrise. We were immediately followed by three other Stages of the same line entirely full. We breakfasted at Dedham, and I was recognized by Genl. M’Neill of the Army, who asked me if he had not some days since passed me in the Street in Boston— I said he had; and he apologized for not having noticed me at that time— I had no desire that he should notice me now; but received his civility with the same indifference as his neglect; accepting his apology exacting nothing from him, and returning in notice just what he gave— Among the Stage-passengers was also Mr Ebenezer Seaver of Roxbury, heretofore a Member of Congress
Precisely at Noon we came to the lower wharf at Providence—called India wharf, where the new Steam-boat, President, Captain Bunker was waiting, and in ten minutes we had left the wharf— Among the Passengers in the Boat, were Mr Daniel Webster a member of the Senate and Mr Hodges a Member of the House of Representatives of the United States from Massachusetts. At Newport where we touched two hours and a quarter after leaving Providence, Mr Dutee J. Pearce, member of Congress from Rhode-Island came on board— An old Captain Justin with whom I had made more than one passage as Master of a Packet, before the invention of the Steamboats, introduced himself to me as an old acquaintance I remembered well his name, and having sailed with him but not his person— He is now a Pilot in this boat— The weather was fine, but there was a breeze, almost a gale, blowing from the Northwest; a head wind for us; which scarcely seemed to slacken our motion; but so cold that I could not keep the Deck— In the Evening several Card parties were made up in the long Cabin. Hodges and Pearce were social as heretofore, but I found Mr Webster averse to conversation, and avoiding to take a share in it when it arose— He had engaged a State-room for himself and me, and then perhaps in courtesy left it wholly to me— He had a daughter with him apparently about twelve years old—
4. V:30. Friday— New-York— Philadelphia—

I found my State-room N. 8. a very uncomfortable birth; the wind blowing in upon me the whole night, and no possibility of getting warmth— I was thoroughly chilled and had no sleep— But our voyage continued rapid and prosperous, and at six this Morning we landed at New-York— I asked Mr Webster when he should proceed on to Washington— he said he did not know— Hodges was quite unwell, with a severe cold taken yesterday— By advice of Captain Bunker, I took a Carriage, and drove to the wharf on the North-river; where I had just time to embark in the Steamboat Trenton Captain Magraw of the Union line for Philadelphia— We left the wharf at seven, and at half-past ten landed at New-Brunswick— In this Boat I met Mr Sprague a Senator of the United States from Maine, with his wife, and a small child— C. C. Cambreleng, a member of the House of Representatives from New-York, with a party male and female in Company. At Mr Cambreleng’s proposal, the Captain of the Boat put me into the Stage with this Company from New-Brunswick to the Landing on the Delaware seven miles below Trenton— There was Mr Tucker of Brooklyne Long Island, with his daughter a lively and beautiful girl of nineteen or twenty; another young Lady whose name I did not ascertain, Mrs Wayne and Mrs Magruder, and a young man of New-York named Hone— The travelling was very rough, the roads having been deep, and frozen hard as marble; we had two or three races with Stages of another line in competition; and one of the proprietors of that line who was in one of their Stages took the trouble to leave it and to come to the doors of each of our Stages, ten in number, to inform us that our drivers would overset our Carriages and break all our Necks. We were four hours and three quarters on the way, and reached the Steam-boat Burlington at a Quarter past three— Miss Tucker had a large paper of Sugar-plums of which Mr Cambreleng was the bearer for her, and which were distributed from time to time to the company, and the weariness of the way was beguiled by a succession of Conundrums and Puns, extemporised by Mr Cambreleng and Mr Hone for the amusement chiefly of Miss Tucker— My forbearance to share in this foolery was owing not to fastidiousness but to barrenness of invention. Arriving at Philadelphia at six in the Evening, I walked to the United States Hotel, Renshaw’s and took a bed-chamber
for the Night— I sent word to Judge Hopkinson that I was here and requested him to call and see me, which he did— Mr John Sergeant also came; and a young man named Adams one of the Editors of the Boston Centinel— Hopkinson spoke of the death of Judge Washington of the United States Supreme Court, who died here on the 26th. of last Month, and of the prospects with regard to the appointment of his Successor. Hopkinson said he had no desire to receive the appointment himself; preferring much that which he now holds of District Judge. There is imminent danger that the appointment will be a bad one. Mr Seymour a Senator of the United States from Vermont also called upon me.
5. VI:15— Saturday— Steam-boat to Newcastle. Stage to Frenchtown.

There are now two Morning lines of Steam-boats and Stages; from Philadelphia to Baltimore; both of which depart at seven O’Clock— One going to the Delaware and Chesapeake Canal; through which the Passengers are conveyed in a Tow-boat; and the other is the old line, travelling in the Stage from Newcastle to Frenchtown— I intended to have gone by the Canal-line, and John Thomas with my baggage went to that boat— There had been a fall of Snow last Evening, which was melting this Morning, and being slippery slackened my pace— After two fruitless enquiries for the Boat, I was directed to the wrong line; and found myself onboard the boat going for Newcastle— The Captain of which told me that the other Boat was gone, which was not true— On this false information however I went on shore and returned to the Hotel— John Thomas and my baggage were in the meantime in the Canal-boat from which after waiting for me several minutes they were landed, and he returned to me— This disappointment vexed me not a little; but it gave me a morning pleasantly employed at Philadelphia— I breakfasted at the common table, and immediately afterwards had a visit from Mr Rutherford of New-Jersey who introduced himself and informed me he was here as a Commissioner on the part of that State with two others to adjust with Commissioners of Pennsylvania, arrangements for the use of the Waters of the Delaware river for the projected Canal, between the Delaware and Raritan— Mr Rutherford was a member of the Senate of the United States from New-Jersey during my fathers Administration and is a worthy and respectable man. Soon after him, Mr Southard came in, returning from attendance on a Court in Salem County, as Attorney General of the State— He has entirely recovered his health, and looks better than he had done for years— His Spirits are also good, and he says he has as much professional business as he can attend to with satisfaction to himself. He gave me many particulars of his attendance last Summer at Washington as a witness on the trial of Dr Watkins. Mr John Vaughan, and Mr Sully the Painter were also with me— Vaughan invited me to the Wistar party this Evening, and said he had arranged that I should dine with Walsh— I had received a previous invitation from John Sergeant, but had determined to proceed in the Steam-boat line at Noon— I gave Mr Sully the engraving of the device of the Eagle and Lyre with the explanation of it in prose and verse which I wrote for Mr Boylston in 1825—and which I was desirous of having introduced in the full length Portrait which Sully is finishing— I went over to the Bank of the United States, and received four dividends of the Stock which I hold in it— Mr Biddle the President invited me to dine with him, which he I declined, and he accompanied me to the Steam-boat— When I
returned to Renshaw’s to go down to the boat, I found there Mr D. J. Pearce whom I had left yesterday Morning at New-York, and had reached Philadelphia this Morning. We went to the Boat together, and at Noon embarked in the Steam-boat for New-castle— There we arrived at four, and proceeded in Stages of which there were only four to Frenchtown— In the Stage with me were Mr and Mrs Pearce, Mr Degen of Leghorn, a young Mr Aspinwall of New-York, and others whom I did not know— At seven in the Evening we reached Frenchtown, and immediately departed in the Steam-boat United States, Captain Trippe; nephew of him with whom I have so often made this passage in Steam-boats and before in Packets, these five and twenty years— I soon found the boat was no longer what it was in his time. He has retired upon his farm, and his laurels— He was one of the best mariners and Commanders with whom I ever have embarked— A dog and cat, and shabby people smoking Cigars, and drinking grog in the Cabin, immediately discovered that he was no longer the Commander.
6. VI:30. Sunday— Baltimore— Washington.

At a quarter past one O’Clock this morning the Steam-boat reached the wharf at Baltimore. The passengers did not land till towards day-light.— I had no sleep, but did not rise from my birth till half past six— Time in the interval dragged on so heavily that my patience deserted me, and I fell to composing verses— Three Stanzas in honour of Miss Tucker my travelling companion, of yesterday, and her Sugar-plum— As thus— Fair damsel, blessing shall the lot, of thy wayfaring partner sweeten; Who shares the Palace or the Cot, with thee, becalm’d or tempest beaten— For him shall little be enough, For him no tangled path-way dreary; Thy smile shall smooth his road when rough; And speed the sand of Time when weary— Fair damsel, may that Angel-form, Of which thy own is but the copy; Which shelters Virtue from the Storm, And steeps the ills of Life in Poppy— That Cherub, which to Fancy’s ken, Watches oer Innocence and Beauty, Chuse for thee from the Sons of Men, A proxy to perform his duty— And thou shalt weather many a wave, And put Life’s Steam-boat on low-pressure; Descend in honour to the Grave, And soar to reap a richer Treasure— Fair Damsel, Fare thee Well— my Eyes, on Earth again may never greet thee— But when thou shalt ascend the Skies— Be mine with welcome first to meet thee.”— At day-light I arose and went to Barnum’s tavern, where I found Mr Seymour, Mr Cambreleng and most of the party with whom I had missed the Canal-line passage of yesterday Morning— I breakfasted at Barnum’s, and with Mr and Mrs Pearce and Mr Degen took passage in a new line of Stages, called Fuller’s, or the Yankee line; in competition with Barnum’s; and so much to his annoyance that his bar keepers attempted to reduce us to the alternative of losing our passage or our breakfast— But the driver who was at Barnum’s door with the Stage, before we sat down, waited until we had breakfasted. We left at Baltimore, Mr Aspinwall, and Mr Chauncey of New-York, our fellow passengers yesterday, but who were going to Richmond— We left Barnum’s just at Nine O’Clock, and took in several other passengers, among whom was Captain Northam of Newport Rhode-Island a fellow traveller with me more than once heretofore; and also the Son of Mr Asbury Dickins— The roads were heavy and the weather warm— We stopped at neither of the Houses where the Stages heretofore have been accustomed to stop—but at Drummond’s, and in the Village of Bladensburg— My fellow travellers alighted at various houses and just after three O’Clock I landed safely, blessed be God, at my Son John’s House on the North side of the President’s Square at Washington— There with feelings of just gratitude I found my wife, my Son and daughter their child, and all the family in health improved, and with better hopes. Glory to God.
7. VII:30. Monday.

The weather was almost at Summer heat and the day too much dissipated. My first visitor was Edward Wyer, complaining of his grievances under the New Administration; they refuse to allow him some of the claims in his Accounts and give him no employment. My wife’s brother Thomas B. Johnson recently returned from a tour of two years in France and Italy was here; and also Mr P. R. Fendall. who afterwards sent me a copy of the Life of Arthur Lee; part of one Volume of which I had read before leaving Quincy. Mrs Frye and Mrs Smith were here, and afterwards Mr Frye— I spent the day at home, but in the Evening walked to the Capitol Hill and called at Judge Cranch’s— He was out, at a Meeting of the Columbian Institute— I delivered to Mrs Cranch a Letter from Mrs John Greenleaf with which I had been charged— I enquired after the Canzonets of Jackson of Exeter; they were remembered, but gone. After returning home, I had visits from Mr Edward Everett, Adams of the Boston Centinel, General Wool and a General Gansevort of New-York, General Macomb and Coll. Roger Jones— General Scott has at length submitted to take his proper Station in the Army. This was the day of Meeting of the first Session of the twenty first Congress— Calhoun’s party made a feeble attempt to choose Virgil Maxcy one of his creatures Clerk of the House of Representatives in the place of Matthew St. Clair Clarke, the late Clerk, and also to turn out the old door-keepers; but without success— The old Officers were all re-elected. The votes were 54 to 136. A still feebler attempt was made to put in a South-Carolina Speaker in the place of Andrew Stevenson—a man named Martin— He got about 30 votes. Stevenson was re-elected by 156 votes, and made a Speech as patriotic and plausible as if he had been an honest man.
8. VI:15. Tuesday.

Weather still warm, and fair, and my time still unprofitably spent. Mr Seymour the Senator from Vermont paid me a morning visit with a Mr St. John. I called to see Mr T. B. Johnson at his house which is in the neighbourhood of ours. The house in which we now live is one built last Winter by my Son John. Meridian Hill, where we resided from March last till June, and whence on the 10th. of that Month I departed for Quincy, was sold in the Month of July, at the close of which month my family removed from it into this House. Mr Daniel Brent paid me a morning visit— And Captain Benjamin Conner aged eighty two came to announce to me that he had discovered the Longitude, and to request me to examine his papers by which it was demonstrated— He proposed to come to-morrow, but I told him I feared I should not understand his papers. Mr Johnson dined with us. The first annual Message of President Jackson was this day transmitted to the two houses of Congress— It is as long as any of those of his Predecessors— As he is very illiterate there was some curiosity to know how the composition would appear— It is apparently the work of several hands—probably of all the heads of Departments—with interpolations from the Telegraph Newspaper, and some passages evidently of his own writing, and of which he suffered nothing but the spelling to be corrected— He recommends an Amendment to the Constitution with regard to the election of President and Vice-President, entirely different from that which he proposed to the Legislature of Tennessee in 1825, but adapted to his own situation now as that was then—equally shallow, and equally certain of not being adopted— He makes a furious sortie against the Bank of the United States; declares his opinion that it is unconstitutional, and recommends in its
stead a Bank, to belong entirely to the Government, exclusively under its controul— He has a paragraph for, and a paragraph against the Tariff, a rap at the Circuit Court of the District for not convicting Watkins upon the Statute, and for convicting him upon the Common Law Jurisdiction: a recommendation to extend the Law limiting the tenure of Executive Offices to four years; and an argument against allowing Offices to be long held by the same persons— These and almost every other opinion in the message are ebullitions of time and occasion suited to popular fancies of the moment; all common-place without a single Sentiment worthy of a philosopher or Statesman— No good can come of them, much mischief may.— He earnestly recommends that the surplus revenue after payment of the debt should be distributed among the States; and packs off all the Indians beyond the bounds of any of the States— The whole message is upon a level with Captain Conner’s discovery of the Longitude.
9. VI:30. Wednesday.

I am still in a state of apathy; unable to resume a course of systematical occupation, and of course dissatisfied with myself. I had as visitors Coll. Dwight, member of the House of Representatives from Massachusetts, with Ambrose Spencer, formerly Chief Justice of New-York, now member of the House from Albany, in the place of General Van Rensselaer, and Benedict Arnold, another member from the State of New-York— Judge Spencer has been a very distinguished politician in the State of New-York, but until now exclusively employed in the Government of the State, having never been in Congress. He remarked that one of his friends had manifested great surprize this day, on his mentioning that he had never seen me— I made some enquiry of him about Coll. Burr; who he told me was living in Solitude, in general contempt, and he believed in wretchedness. Baron Stackelberg the Swedish Charge d’Affaires was also here—a Mr Cofield of Norfolk, who was one of my fellow passengers from Philadelphia, and who told me he was a friend and supporter of Mr Newton, came and introduced himself. Coll. W. H. Drayton, member of the House of Representatives from South Carolina was here; a visit remarkable as the solitary instance of civility from any person of his description of Politics since my return— There is indeed among them all not a man of character so estimable as that of Drayton, and he is not worth much— Mr White the Delegate from Florida was here much dissatisfied with the removals from Office in Florida, and still more so with the substituted appointments; of which he says the holders are all insolvents; almost universally of bad character— In the Evening Mr Newton, a member of the House of Representatives from Norfolk, Virginia, who is the father of the House, and has been a member 26-years in succession— His Seat is now contested, and although he is sangwine in the expectation of retaining it, I think he will lose it— I walked this day before dinner to Georgetown, and made an effort to commence upon some useful occupation without success— My thoughts are all scattered in dissipation— I finished reading the Memoir of the Life of Arthur Lee, which is in five Chapters and occupies 183 pages of the first Volume— The remainder of this Volume and the whole of the second are occupied with eleven Appendixes, containing much of his Correspondence public and private—fragments of Journal and sketches of the early part of the American Revolution— The Life itself consists in a great measure of extracts from his Correspondence, and there appears to be a want of method, and especially of chronological arrangement in the composition of the Book— It is nevertheless highly interesting.
10. VI. Thursday.

How much of the regularity of life depends upon mechanical habits. I find already so much inconvenience in waiting till the Middle of the day for the day’s exercise that I resumed this morning my old practice of walking before Breakfast— I went round the Capitol Square, and was out precisely an hour and a quarter 38 minutes to the central gate and 37 minutes returning— Dr Huntt called and paid me a visit— I congratulated him upon his recent Marriage with one of the daughters of Tench Ringgold the Marshal of this District— Mr Wyer brought some papers relating to the Settlement of his accounts which he wished me to examine; with a view to obtain a recommendation from me of certain charges which have been disallowed. I told him that I would readily examine them if I could be of any Service to him; but if Mr Van Buren wanted my opinion upon the charges to make up his own he must say so in writing; otherwise my recommendation if I should give it would be a decisive reason for rejecting the items of which I should recommend the allowance— Judge Cranch was here. The Circuit Court of the District have yesterday adjourned their Session at Alexandria, and are now sitting here— The judge spoke of the insulting reflection in the Message upon the proceedings of the Court in the case of Dr. Watkins— I thought it was what might have been expected, but acknowledged with great pain to the judge my own impression that the decision of the Court, in convicting an Officer of the United States for official malversation under an assumed Common Law Jurisdiction was erroneous— He noticed the distinctions upon which the Court gave their Judgment— The Jurisdiction of the Court derived from the Laws of Maryland: and the fraud in the Transactions of the public officer which they considered as independent of his official character— But I could not comprehend those distinctions— The frauds were such as could be committed by no other than a public Officer, and the real motives to the prosecution were mere political malice and personal revenge— This the judge admitted, and said the rancour with which the prosecution was conducted was beyond the conception of any one who had not witnessed it— Mr Johnson called here also this Morning.
11. V. Friday.

Both houses of Congress, adjourned over from yesterday till next Monday and I had a succession of Visitors all this day long, chiefly of members of Congress, of those who were friendly to the last Administration— Several Members from the State of Ohio, all of whom were known to me excepting Mr Creighton, whom I had appointed and then nominated Judge of the United States District Court in that State. He was one of those whom the Senate did not confirm. I enquired of Mr Clarke the Representative of the District of Mr Clay, of the state of his health which he says he has entirely recovered. He adds that Mr Clay is leading a very active life but is not in much practice at the Bar— I asked Mr Foote if he could ascertain who were the authors of the Essays signed Pelham in the winter of 1796 in the Connecticut Courant; and how many of them were published— He said he would ascertain, but that he believed the authors of Pelham were Mr Terry; and Timothy and Theodore Dwight— Young Buckingham is a Son of the Editor of the Boston Courier— Russell Freeman has come here to make the attempt to recover his Office of Collector of the Customs at New-Bedford. Mr Taylor spoke with some despondency of the State of politics in the State of

New-York, and particularly of the mischievous effects of the Anti-masonic hurricane which is sweeping over the State— Taylor told me that the votes given to Martin last Monday for Speaker were by our friends and that he would probably have been elected if he had held out as a Candidate— That on Sunday Evening he told Vance who enquired of him that he was a Candidate; but that on Monday when the election came on he flinched and declined. Mr Brook is a Quaker of Montgomery County Maryland; and came with Mr Bayley. Edes the Constable came to enquire if there had been any plate stolen from the President’s House while I was there— I said there had not. He said there was information from Philadelphia, that a man taken up there had made confession that he had stolen Plate from the President’s House and hidden it under ground— It appears to have been on the 4th. of March last at Mr Jackson’s inauguration— I wrote this day to my brother and sent him a draught of a Petition to the Court of Common Pleas of Norfolk County Massachusetts for the appointment of Commissioners to set off in severalty to me, ten Acres of Woodland in the six-hundred Acres, from the remnant of Lands returned by the Supplementary Inventory, to the Judge of Probate, as part of my father’s Estate.
12. VI. Saturday.

Mr Crane is a new Member of the House of Representatives and came with Mr Vance; as did the other person—whose name I perhaps mistook— There is no member at present of the name of Wright— Mr Ellis is a Clergyman from the State of Illinois, and came to solicit a subscription for establishing a College in some part of that State— He said they wanted to raise 10,000 dollars. He had obtained subscriptions for 9200, and he was applying to make up the remainder; part of the actual subscriptions being conditional—provided that the whole sum shall be procured. I declined making any contribution—telling him that the multitude of applications of this kind from every part of the Country made it necessary to assume some principle concerning them— The principle I thought should be to contribute to them all, or to none— I had while in Office practised upon the former, and was now by my circumstances compelled to act upon the latter of these Rules— He asked me whether I thought Congress would grant any of the Public Lands to such an Institution; and what my own opinion was of the propriety of such a measure— I told him that my own opinion was in favour of the measure; and I knew of no better use that could be made of public Lands; but it was quite improbable that a Majority of the two houses of Congress were of the same opinion; and mentioned the failure of Bishop Chase of Ohio, in a similar application under circumstances far more favourable to its success than those now existing— I walked round the Capitol Square this morning; and soon after my return there came on heavy rain which continued till Night, and then a very heavy Gale from the Northwest swept away all the clouds and the Evening was clear and cold. I am yet torpid, and wasting time— Finished reading the first Volume of the Life of Arthur Lee— There was something acrimonious in his temper—and perhaps over suspicious— He became extremely distrustful of Dr Franklin’s fidelity to the cause even before 1775 and during their joint Commission in France still more so— Franklin, Deane, Jonathan Williams, Carmichael, Beaumarchais and Dr Bancroft were so associated that they actually broke down Lee— Deane undoubtedly invited sordid private speculation with his public trust Beaumarchais seems to have painted himself in his own Figaro— Dr Bancroft’s part in the Drama was always mysterious. Williams was commercial Agent, Commission Merchant and Dr Franklin’s Nephew, and between them all a Million of franks disappeared, which the Heirs of Beaumarchais are still claiming of the United States.
13. V:30. Sunday.— Sun rose 7:23.

The Sun rose this morning upon a perfectly clear horizon, an occurrence more rare in this Country more rare than any one would imagine—without long continued observation— It set also perfectly clear and it being close at the Solstice, I noted the position of its rising and setting from the windows at its extreme Southern Declination— At the Presbyterian Church I heard Mr Campbell from Hebrews 11.25. “Choosing rather to suffer affliction with the people of God, than to enjoy the pleasures of sin for a season.” He gave a succinct historical account of Moses, from his birth to the time of his choosing to suffer with the people of God— The historical part was handsomely told, and the inferences deduced from it as example and warning were well drawn. He enquired why the example, glorious as it stands is so rarely imitated by those who profess to be Christians and answered because practically they do not believe the Scriptures— This is a favourite conclusion of Mr Campbell’s which I have heard him draw before— He gave notice that he was to preach this afternoon at the Orphan Asylum, and that the Evening service at his Church would begin at a quarter before 7. Also that the funeral of Dr Staughton formerly the President of the Columbian College, would be at two this afternoon from the Residence of his Son— After the Morning service I had visits from Messrs. Cutts, Barrell, Graham and Swann, and in the Evening from Mr Frye and Mr Silsbee. Mr Frye’s mentioned his Accounts as Guardian of Thomas J. Hellen, and some difficulties which he has in obtaining a Settlement of them by the Judge of the Orphan’s Court— He mentioned some extraordinary mistakes of the judge concerning them, which I thought he should insist upon having corrected, and he said he would— Mr Silsbee informed me that his Colleague Daniel Webster was married last Evening to Miss Le Roy, a daughter of my old friend Herman Le Roy at New-York. There has been much speculation lately upon Mr Webster’s matrimonial pursuits; and some expectation of his removal from Boston to New-York; an event highly probable— My Sons infant daughter who for several months has been suffering severely with the whooping cough was very ill with it this afternoon and evening.
14. V:30. Monday.

Mrs Adams was up the whole Night with the Child; to visit whom Dr Huntt was sent for in the night— She was a little better this day; but is very dangerously ill— The morning was fine but cold— I walked round the Capitol Square and met Coll. John Crowell the Agent to the Creek Indians; who told me he arrived here yesterday— William Brown was here this morning, and promised to call again in the Evening to execute the Conveyances which he had promised me as security for the sum of 500 dollars which he borrowed of me last Spring. He told me that he had not been able to obtain employment at New York; and upon returning here in the Summer had got a small Clerkship of 400 dollars a year in the Bank of Washington; that Mr Van Buren had employed him to make a detailed Statement of his Accounts for Settlement, for which he had allowed him a compensation, and had since given him some occasional work of copying. Russell
Freeman came and informed me of the measures he has taken with the delusive hope of obtaining the restitution of his place—gave me a copy of the pamphlet which he has printed containing documents exhibiting the political Sentiments of the late and present Collector of New-Bedford to prove his own republicanism, and the federalism of his Successor Lemuel Williams. He says that the President and Ingham told him that the appointment of Williams had been made by mistake, and that if they had known then what they know now, it would not have been made; but that they could not now dismiss Mr Williams without cause; and that George M Troup and Felix Grundy Senators told him if the President or Ingham would say as much to the Senate they would reject the nomination of Williams— Mr Freeman has however given up all hope of this— He gave me the original copy of my poor Son George’s spark at Sea; which George gave him and which he published in the New-Bedford Newspaper. Dr Semple and Coll. Towson came and invited me to attend at the Commencement of the Columbian College next Wednesday Morning at Mr Post’s Presbyterian Church— Dr Semple told me they had only seven Students to take the Bachelor’s degree. Mr Bates member of the House of Representatives from Massachusetts, and Mr Storrs from New-York were here; and afterwards Genl. Van Rensselaer of Albany and his Son. Storrs and Bates were complaining that they could not obtain access to the President, who they were told was always engaged, and Storrs spoke with great contempt of the Report of the Secretary of War, communicated to Congress among the documents at the Commencement of the present Session of Congress.
15. V:30— Tuesday.

My Son John’s child continues so ill, that Mrs Adams was again up with her till two O’Clock this Morning; and by these excessive exertions so overstrained herself that she was herself taken very ill, and took to her bed this evening with an extremely violent fever. I took my walk round the Capitol Square before breakfast, and the remainder of the day was without interruption of visitors— With the exception of the time occupied in retrieving the arrears of this Journal, not yet completed the day was absorbed in the assortment and filing of a collection and bundles of my fathers papers, in one of his trunks, which I know not how was some years since separated from the rest, and sent from Quincy here— Now for the first time I am over hawling the papers and find it will be at least a full week’s labour to arrange and label them if I had nothing else to do— They will I have no doubt take all my leisure time for a fortnight— They consist almost entirely of Letters written and received while my father was President of the United States—most of them during the last year of that time— A year of severe trial to him; and to my mother as these papers painfully testify.
16. V:30— Wednesday.

Walking round the Capitol Square this Morning I met three Irishmen, one of whom enquired of me the way to Baltimore, which I pointed out to him, and then enquired whence he and his companions came. He said from working upon the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal— That they had been working there these six weeks and could get no pay— That it had been even refused to them yesterday, and they had determined to wait no longer— They were going to try their hands at the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad—W. Browne called and left the Deeds of the Lands which he proposes to convey as security for the payment of the money which he borrowed of me last Spring— I had morning visits from Mr Letcher, a member of the House of Representatives from Kentucky Mr Knight, Senator
from Rhode-Island, Commodore Rodgers, and Mr Adams of the Boston Centinel. Mr Letcher spoke of Mr Clay who he said had entirely recovered his health, and of Mr John Pope, now Governor of the Territory of Arkansas, and who has been making a ridiculous dinner table Speech there— Rodgers appears to be much dissatisfied, with the present management of the Navy Department; and particularly with the projects for forcing down double quantities of Rice, for the food of the Seaman, and Cotton Sails and Cordage for the Line of Battle Ships; with which he declared he would not go to Sea— He laughed heartily at the proposal of the Report of John Branch Secretary of the Navy, to lop off the unprofitable Branches of the Service. Adams has just returned from Richmond, where the Virginian Convention are squabbling upon the Amendment of their Constitution— Mr Monroe, the President of the Convention has resigned that Office, and his Seat in the Convention itself. Adams was wishing to know who was to be supported for the next Presidential Election, and was himself disposed to support Mr Clay. I walked out in the middle of the day and called upon Baron Krudener, Mrs Rush, Mr Vaughan, and the Chevalier Huygens, none of whom were at home or visible— Mr Frye called here this morning, and brought me this Evening a paper of 13 folio pages, drawn up by the Judge of the Orphans Court in the form of a decree upon my account of monies advanced by me for the Education of Thomas J. Hellen while he was at Exeter and at Cambridge— This paper is full of errors too gross to be attributed to mere misapprehension, and it seems to me must have been written when the man was drunk— Mr Frye had written a paper refuting some of its most egregious misstatements; but I desired him to inform the Judge that if any thing like that paper was to assume the form of a decree; I should claim the privilege of being heard against it in my own vindication, and I desired him particularly to give explanations upon every item of the charges which the judge’s paper misrepresented; which was almost every one in the account— I am reading this day besides the Correspondence of Arthur Lee two or three Articles, in the last published numbers of the North-American and of the American Quarterly Review. And made some progress in the assortment of my fathers papers.
17. VI. Thursday.

A strolling Bookseller by the name of M’Manus came with several publications by subscription, none of which I inclined to take; and I had a morning visit from Mr John Read a member of the House of Representatives from Massachusetts. I finished a Letter begun yesterday to my Son Charles, and read some pages of the Correspondence of Arthur Lee; the Article in the North-American Review upon Captain Basil Hall’s Travels in the United States and five Sections of Cicero’s first Book de Oratore— The Review of Captain Hall’s Travels is by Mr Edward Everett, mild and moderate, but castigating— Hall’s Travels themselves are as from his deportment in this Country it was expected they would be libels upon it. If there be among us an undue portion of National Vanity, the splenetic effusions of these foreign travellers, are well suited to operate as wormwood upon it— A British traveller who should find any thing in this Country deserving of commendation, if he could find in England a publisher of his work, would not find readers to pay for the publication— Satire and Slander on the other hand are sure of meeting a welcome reception— They minister to the envious and rancorous passions which are felt by almost the whole Nation— They are sure of falling in with the current of popular feeling. This of itself will account for the temper of almost all the British Tourists in the United States— But Captain Hall was also an Officer in the British Navy; that portion of the Empire which
had suffered the deepest humiliation in their recent conflicts with ours; and he could lay no more flattering unction to the Souls of his Superiors than by feeding their vindictive passions with obloquy upon the Americans— Of all this no notice is taken in Mr Everett’s Review. There is not so much resentment in the Review as the Book deserves— There is more of concession and less severity of animadversion than there should have been—
18. V. Friday.

There was a fall of sleet, this morning; but not such as to deprive me of my early walk. I had a visit from Mr Pedersen the Minister Resident from Denmark who comes from his Residence at Philadelphia to pass a few days at Washington, at the Commencement of every Session of Congress— Mr Davis, member of the House of Representatives from Massachusetts came with Mr Grennell and Mr Kendall, one of whom comes in the place of S. C. Allen and the other in that of Mr Locke— I wrote to Joseph Blunt and to Charles March at New-York, and read several Articles in the North-American Review; part of the Correspondence of Arthur Lee, and about half the first Book of Cicero de Oratore— Received a Letter from my Son Charles; from which it appears that my last Letter to him had been broken open before he received it— One of the Articles in the North-American Review which I read was upon historical composition, Spanish History, and Irving’s Chronical of Grenada— Another upon the never to be settled question who was the author of Junius— A new attempt to fit the cap upon the head of Lord George Germain—or Sackville— There are two remarkable things in all these inquisitions after Junius— One that the known, and public writings of the suspected persons bear no comparison to the anonymous writings— The other that there is not a writer in the language whose style exactly resembles that of Junius— Burke and Chatham have resemblances to him and both have been suspected; but there is a diffuseness in Burke, which it was impossible for him to discard, and Burke could not imitate that admirable variety in the Structure of his Sentences which constitutes one of the most attractive charms of Junius— Burke’s Sentences are almost invariably long. They always combine complicated thought— He is never laconic— Burke’s Model was Cicero— The Model of Junius was Tacitus, sublimated by a deep study of Juvenal— Junius had studied the antient theories of prosaic numbers— So had Burke—but Junius had adapted those doctrines to the composition of English prose more successfully than Burke— Dr Bollmann proposed to some of the European Governments to use Platina for their coins, because from the specific gravity of that metal it could not be counterfeited— A coin of the size of a dollar of that metal, would press with nearly double the weight of silver upon the hand— The Style of Junius is to the Style of Burke, like Platina to Silver: and by the same analogy the Style of Lord Sackville would be no better than Tin, and that of Sir Philip Francis scarcely better than lead— Lord Chatham’s Speeches sometimes bear to it the comparative gravity of gold, but their colour is not the same. For profound philosophy Burke far transcends them all, but for keen penetrating misanthropical observation of human nature Junius is again unrivalled— The philosophy of Burke was tempered with the morals of Christianity— Junius was deistical and worldly minded— Junius was a principled duelist, and an encomiast of Suicide— Burke at least in principle abhorred them both. Junius was a splendid Genius and a bad man.— I think that neither Burke nor Chatham was a bad man, although in the corrupted currents of the world, their virtues were often tarnished by their interests and their Passions—
19— V:30. Saturday.

The Succession of visitors occupied the greater part of the day. They were principally members of Congress friendly to the last Administration. Those of the other party have had the modesty to abstain, with a single exception— The Message of President Jackson is not only satisfactory to his party, but is puffed to the skies by his newspaper pack with one general howl of extasy— All the Reports of all the Heads of Departments are cried up with the same yell of admiration— They are all papers below mediocrity; but the Report of J. H. Eaton the Secretary of War defies all criticism— I meet with a parallel to it in a Letter from a member of the Pennsylvania Legislature, in the second Volume of the Life of Arthur Lee, page 382— Many of my visitors speak of it with grave disgust, but I told one of them that I had not laughed so heartily at reading any thing since my first acquaintance with the expedition of Humphrey Clinker— Holmes said that his ex-Colleague John Chandler at the last Session of the Senate voted to put off the decision of my nomination to the Office of Collector at Portland, till the accession of the new Administration, that he might get the Office himself, as he did. Mr Bell considered the proceedings of President Jackson last Spring, in closing the Session of the Senate by a Declaration that he had no further communication to make to them, and immediately afterwards removing several persons and appointing others to their Offices during the recess, the Offices being of those which require the Confirmation of the Senate, were a violation of the Spirit of the Constitution— While we were at dinner Mr Elliot and Mr Cranch called as a Committee from the Unitarian Society to inform me that as a mark of respect to me the Society had reserved my old pew in their Church, for my use, if I should be inclined to occupy it— I desired them to present my thanks to the Society and say that I should avail myself of their offer and would take the pew for the Winter— I finished reading the first Book of Cicero de Oratore.
20. V. Sunday— Sun rose 7:24.

The Sun rose clear and my Chronometer had gained 3 minutes and 25 seconds on the Sun since this day week, the last clear Sunrise before this. This is precisely what the Sun has in the same time lost upon the Clock; but the Sun really rose from one to two minutes later than it did last Sunday— That time my Chronometer has lost—about ten seconds a day: it sometimes loses more; sometimes less— The average since I set the hands two hours in advance the 1st. of last June has been 16. seconds a day— My wife went with me this morning and heard Mr Campbell at the Presbyterian Church, from 1. John 5.4. “For whatsoever is born of God overcometh the world; and this is the victory that overcometh the world, even our faith.” The Discourse was eloquent; and it was not possible to resist the impression that many of its allusions had reference to his own present situation— He baptised a female child— After the morning service I left Cards at Mr B. O. Tayloe’s for him and Mr Dickinson, at Kervand’s for Coll. W. H. Drayton; and for Baron Krudener at his house— I intended to have called on Mr T. Munroe, but met him in the street. In the Evening I heard Mr Campbell again, from Acts 7.59. “And they stoned Stephen, calling upon God, and saying Lord Jesus, receive my Spirit”— And in describing the persecutions, the
fortitude, the sufferings, and the triumphant death of the first Christian Martyr, his invincible adherence to the Cause of his Master, his inextinguishable contempt and scorn of all that the world could inflict upon him, the outrages of profligate power that he is himself enduring could not but occur to the minds of his Auditory.— His Lecture was short and spirited— Mr T. B. Johnson spent the Evening here— I finished reading the Memoirs of Arthur Lee— The Correspondence discloses much more than the Life— A Letter from John Dickinson shews in clear relief the cause which arrested Lee in his career of honourable service abroad, and as a public man crippled him for life— It was his quarrel with Franklin and the consequent influence of the Count de Vergennes against him— This displaced him from the Commission to Spain and undoubtedly from the final Commission for negotiating the Peace— It made way both for Jay and Jefferson— There is room for remark in this Correspondence which extends from 1765 to 1787. both on the different tones of the times, of the same writers at different times, and of different writers at the same times— Among the most remarkable Letters are those of Samuel Adams, among which there is one containing a backhanded blow at his fellow Patriot T. Cushing which shews at once his opinion of Cushing, and a specimen of that quality which Hutchinson in his third Volume imputes to S. Adams— The very short fragments of Arthur’s Journals, and Memoirs are also deeply interesting. Most particularly that of his Indian Negotiation— He avows a profound contempt for the Indian character— The view of his own situation prospects and purposes given in the midst of the Journal of this Negotiation, would make a Scene for the Vieux Celibataire of Collin d’Harleville— Lee destroyed his own prospects, or at least turned the tide of his own Fortunes; by uniting with stern unaccommodating Virtue a certain asperity of manner. He was finally shooed off of the political stage, for his opposition to the Constitution of the United States; and did not live till it would have operated as a recommendation to bring him forward again— I wrote to Dr Waterhouse and to my Son Charles.
21. VI. Monday— Winter Solstice— Sun rose 7:24.

Day of the Winter Solstice— The Sun rose clear again and my Chronometer had apparently gained ten seconds since yesterday. As the Sun had actually gained 30. my Chronometer had lost 20— Mr Dickins the Secretary of the Columbian Institute brought me a draught of a Petition from that Body to Congress for a grant of money to fence round their garden— He said that Judge Cranch and he had been appointed a Committee to prepare the Petition— It had been drawn up by the judge, and as it was to be signed by me as President of the Institute, he offered to leave with me for consideration— I declined retaining it, and told him that as the annual Elections of the Officers of the Institute was coming in a few days, I would thank him to present my respects to the Society, and to request that the Petition to Congress might be deferred until after the election— And with my very sincere and cordial thanks to the Institute for the honour they had done me for a series of years in electing me their President to ask of them the favour now to confer that distinction upon another person— I said I had wished to avoid writing a formal Letter to that effect, and was glad to have this opportunity of communicating to the Institute my wishes and intentions in this manner through him— He said he knew that the Institute would wish me to reconsider this Resolution. That if I would consent merely to countenance the Institution by my name, my election as President would be as it always had been unanimous— That there was not a dissenting voice on the subject, and that the Society would earnestly regret my determination to withdraw from the Presidency if I should persist in it— I told him I was fully aware of and deeply sensible to the kind feelings of the members of the Institute in my favour
but I had always been conscious of my inability to serve them in such manner as to justify their choice— While in the public service it had been impossible for me to devote the Time to the Society, as I should have desired— There were now other causes which deprived me of that power, and I was sure my name would do them more harm than good— He asked me, if I should be disposed to yield to a distinct expression of opinion by the Society on this subject?— I said I had such implicit confidence in the friendly feelings of the members of the Institute that I had no doubt of the opinion they would express— But my own mind was so fully made up, that if they should re-elect me, I should be compelled to decline accepting their favour which would be painful to me— I could not attend the meetings of the Society. It might perhaps not always be so— If a time should come in which I could serve the Society by attendance upon its Meetings, I should give it with pleasure. At present I was satisfied it would be best served by my absence— He took back accordingly the draught of the petition. I had also a morning visit from Mr Hawley— After dinner I called with my wife at her brother’s but he was not at home.
22. V. Tuesday.— Sun rose 7.24.

The Sun rose clear: my Chronometer appearing to have gained ten seconds since yesterday morning— I went round the Capitol Square in an hour and five minutes, but the exercise was too violent, and threw up the internal inflammation into my throat— Mr Danforth the revival Calvinist Minister was here with his brother was here— He invited me to attend the exhibition of the infant School at the Masonic Hall, next Tuesday Morning at ten O’Clock— He asked me many questions which I was perhaps too ready to answer— I spent great part of the morning in arranging the papers of my father which were in the trunk accidentally sent here— I left a Card at Mr Swan’s, and called at Mr Frye’s. Neither he nor Mrs Frye was at home; but as I was returning I met and spoke with him. John’s wife dined there, and mine with John spent the Evening with them— I wrote to Charles’s wife, and read nearly half the second Dialogue of Cicero de Oratore. This Treatise is altogether different form the usual works which treat of Rhetoric. It gives the subject a popular form; and discusses all the Secrets of the Art, under the appearance of contesting the pretensions of Oratory to be styled an Art— The book is addressed to his brother Quintus, who had requested him to give his opinions upon the general subject of Eloquence— In the first Section he laments in a feeling manner the turbulent and stormy times in which it had always been his fortune to live, and which had made it impossible for him to devote much of his leisure to literature and philosophy, as he would have wished— Yet he says that notwithstanding the harshness and distresses of his Times, he has devoted to writing every hour of leisure which the persecution of his enemies; the professional defence of his friends and the service of his Country had allowed him— An example which ought to be followed by every virtuous man— He then undertakes to set forth the opinions of the most illustrious Orators upon the art of speaking in general—and mentions the rhetorical Treatises published in his youth as mere undigested compilations, altogether unworthy of his riper age and more practised experience— He states a difference of opinion between his brother and himself—he considering eloquence as a
Talent, acquired by the studies of profound philosophy; while Quintus thought it a gift of natural Genius, wrought up to perfection by practice— In confirmation of his own opinion Cicero starts the question how it happens that there have lived so very few masters of Eloquence— That among multitudes of eminent Statesmen, Warriors, Mathematicians, Musicians and even Poets, the great Orators are scarcely more than two or three—and he accounts for it by the assertion that the great Orator must be conversant with the whole circle of the Sciences— He then supposes that at a period not long preceding his own age, Lucius Crassus at the annual Season of the Roman Games, went to pass a few days of relaxation at Tusculanum, where he was visited by Quintus Mucius who had been his father in Law; by Marcus Antonius; Gaius Cotta, and Publius Sulpicius— Between these the first Dialogue is held—the discussion being chiefly confined to Crassus and Antony.
23. III. and V. Wednesday— Sun rose 7:24.

The consequence of my violent exercise yesterday Morning has almost laid me up— I rose in the Night and finding it only three O’Clock retired again to bed and lay without sleeping till five— I nevertheless walked round the Capitol Square, and returned to see the Sun rise clear the fourth day in succession. My Chronometer had apparently gained 20 Seconds since yesterday Morning; but the horizon was this morning not perfectly clear— There was a haze which probably delayed for 10 Seconds the appearance of the Sun— Mr Gerry the Surveyor of the Port of Boston, called to see me; and said he was here to secure if possible his re-appointment to his office— His term of four years will expire next Month, and there are Cormorants abroad in search after it— He said the President had promised to renominate him as soon as the Senate should be ready to receive his nominations; and Mr Ingham had promised his influence in his favour. None of the nominations have been yet sent in the two Virginia Senators being detained in the Convention; and Mr Reed the Senator from Mississippi having died while on his way to this place. With these three vacancies, there is some doubt whether all the Nominations would be confirmed— Mr Gerry notwithstanding the promises he has received is under much anxiety, his mother’s comfortable support as well as his own depending upon his place— He told me that while I was at the head of the Government, he took a pride in the public Service; but now he was obliged to pocket his Pride which I approved— Mr T. B. Johnson was here in the Evening. I retired after a footbath early to bed quite unwell. I am much engaged and consume much time in assorting papers— Those of the Trunk belonging to my father, are not yet assorted, and this afternoon I took up those of Mr Benjamin Vaughan— I made little progress with them being somewhat dispirited, a state of mind which I cannot entirely controul. I am drawing however towards the close of the second Dialogue of Cicero de Oratore— The discussion in the first Dialogue is between Crassus who maintains that Oratory is an Art, and that the perfect Orator should be a man of universal Science; and Antonius who considers it all as depending on Genius and practice— In the second Dialogue which the author represents as having taken place the next day; he introduces two new Interlocutors. Quintus Catulus and Gaius Julius Caesar, the father I suppose of the Dictator— They join the party upon hearing of the discussion of the preceding day— The first part of the second Dialogue is discursive, and several of the Speakers alternately take part in it— In the latter part Caesar expounds very philosophically the whole theory of facetiousness and joking; as of great power in the practice of Oratory— There are also some remarks upon demonstrative Oratory, Panegyrics and funeral Eulogies which Cicero considers as scarcely belonging to the Art.
24. IV. and IV:30. Thursday.

After a very uneasy Night I rose at four, and again half an hour afterwards, suffering with an oppression of phlegm upon the lungs, which depresses the Spirits beyond the Power of Philosophy.— I began writing an Essay without any distinct purpose, which occupied me till my usual hour for walking— Received a Letter from Joseph Blunt which I answered. Mr Brown late Minister of the United States in France, whence he has recently returned called and spent an hour with me this Evening— Mrs Brown is in bad health and has been so ill that it was one cause of their returning home— They have taken up a temporary residence in Philadelphia— Mr Currier was nominated by me last winter as Collector of the Customs at Newbury-Port, and confirmed by the Senate— In June he was removed and a Mr Phillips of Andover appointed in his place— He Currier had one of the largest lists of recommendation from the merchants of Newbury-Port that I ever received; and he says his friends could not conceive that he should have been removed without cause— Mr William Bartlett in particular he said had expressed that opinion, and advised him to demand what the cause was he therefore came here, and applied to the Secretary of the Treasury Ingham, who refused to assign to him any other reason, but that there had been a great political contest— I had never seen Mr Currier before, but he said he called to return me thanks for my nomination of him. He had been the deputy of the preceding Collector, and the whole business of the Office, had been for some years transacted by him. I finished reading the second and began the third Dialogue de Oratore— The introduction to the third is an eloquent and pathetic lamentation, at the tragical end of most of the Interlocutors of the Work— He says that Crassus died within ten days after the time at which he has fixed the Dialogues as held— Died of a fever occasioned by high political excitement; and that Catulus, Antonius, Julius Caesar, Cotta and Sulpicius all afterwards died violent Deaths— And as if with a prophetic forecast of his own fate, he acknowledges that the advice which his brother Quintus had often given him to take warning from all these cruel Catastrophes, and abstain from exposing himself to the same calamities had been wise and good— But he says it is no longer possible for him to chuse his course— That his labours and dangers have been in some degree compensated by glory, and that in the midst of them he turns with delight to the studies and meditations of his youth.
25. IV:15— Christmas.

The weather was almost at Summer heat and the day clear though just before Sun rise a fog beclouded the horizon so that I could not mark the moment of his first beam— Mrs Adams went to Church at Mr Hawley’s. I had a succession of morning visitors who engrossed the day. Mr Everett told me that Baron Krudener had expressed his wish to visit me in the course of a few days and that I would receive him; which I said I would do with great pleasure— He said the Baron was going in a few days to Boston with Captain Stephanoff, and another Russian Naval Officer who are here with Instructions from their Government to visit our Navy-Yards and Docks. I told Mr Everett that I wished to have some conversation with him, and would call upon him one of these Mornings for that purpose— Mr Ringgold

mentioned that he had heard yesterday Morning from Mr Monroe who is very ill at Richmond, though upon the recovery— He has resigned his Seat, both as President and member of the Virginia Convention— Mr Watts was Secretary of the Legation of the United States at St. Petersburg; but upon some misunderstanding with Mr Middleton the Minister has come home and now claims the right to go back again in the same capacity. John A. Smith, displaced from the Office of Secretary of the Legation to France is said to have received a Commission for that in Russia— Dr Huntt told me that the Chevalier Huygens the Minister from the Netherlands had asked him whether I would accept any invitation to dinner—he said he was very desirous of inviting me, but had heard that I declined the invitation of Mr Vaughan— I desired Dr Huntt to say to Mr Huygens, that I should be happy to call and see him, and to receive him at my own house frequently; but that I did not wish for the present to attend at dining parties abroad— Mr Featherstonhaugh told me that he had within these two or three years suffered a variety of the most distressing calamities— The deepest of which was the death of his wife— Another was the loss of his house and valuable library by fire; of which I had heard— He has been sometime within these two years in Europe. Commodore Warrington called with Mr King, heretofore Navy Agent at Norfolk, but dismissed by the present Administration. Mr Cambreleng gave me a very pleasant account of the remainder of the Journey of him and his company after we parted— I have preserved perfect good humour with this person, who is one of the most inveterate and malignant political enemies I have in the world— Mr Smith called to see me, the first time since my return from Quincy— I enquired of Mr Brent for the Journals of both Houses of Congress, and the Public Documents of the last Session; of which he said he was collecting a set to send me— I asked him also if I could occasionally borrow some books which I wished to consult from the library of the Department of State, to which he answered he had no doubt Mr Van Buren, would readily consent— Mr T. B. Johnson dined and spent the Evening with us.
26. IV:45. Saturday.

Last Night precisely at the time of the New Moon, a great change took place in the weather from fair and warm, to storming and rain— It continued foul this Morning; notwithstanding which I took my morning pilgrimage round the Capitol Square; an hour and a quarter, in returning from which I was nearly drenched in rain— My hoarse cold has settled into a deeper seated cough; in no wise relieving the pressure upon my lungs and my Spirits— I wrote a long answer to a Letter, received yesterday from my Son Charles. I read a few Sections in the third Dialogue of Cicero de Oratore— The principal Speaker in this Dialogue is Crassus, and it is evidently the purpose of the writer to raise the tone of his Discourse to the highest pitch of eloquence as it draws towards the close— His account of the Grecian Systems of Philosophy, and of their application to the purposes of Oratory from the 16th. to the 22d. Section is magnificent— His exclusion of the Epicurean and Stoic doctrines is expressed with the greater force, because in terms of mildness and urbanity. The management of these dialogues is remarkable for the elegant politeness of the speakers to each other, and the easiness with which the conversation is distributed among the individuals engaged in it. The tone of conversation is preserved throughout, and the profoundest precepts of the art are interwoven into the conference, with such exquisite skill, that you seem to enjoy the amusement of a Comedy while you are insensibly
learning the Science of Rhetoric, and if so endowed, the Art of Oratory. In the Evening I returned to the Manuscripts of Mr Benjamin Vaughan, and read several of his Letters to the Earl of Shelburne, afterwards Marquis of Lansdown written in the last half of the year 1782 and the first quarter of 1783. during the Negotiation of the Preliminaries of Peace between Great-Britain and the United States— They are deeply interesting Letters, but Mr Vaughan has communicated them to me in the closest confidence, and has lately written to me requesting me to return them. They afford decisive proof of the liberality of Lord Shelburne’s Views, in the Negotiation of the Peace, and they have convinced me that his Merits as a Statesman have been and are yet generally much underrated. He rose indeed three degrees in the peerage of England— A reward splendid enough to indicate the estimation in which his services were held, by his Sovereign George the third; but of all the Statesmen of the Time he appears to have stooped the least to the Idols of faction and to have been the least bolstered up by them— He was neither Whig nor Tory.
27. IV. Sunday.

Heard at the Unitarian Church a young man, named Lincoln, from Fitchburg—Massachusetts: from John 15.13. [“]Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends.” the great doctrine of the Christian Religion, with reference to this world is benevolence and it is almost exclusively the subject of the Sermons of the Unitarian preachers— The doctrine is good, but by perpetual repetition, like the atonement of Calvinism palls upon the understanding. Mr Lincoln’s elocution is also very affected and disagreeable— After the Service I called on Mr and Mrs Brown at Gadsby’s— Mrs Brown has been more than two years in declining health, but appeared lively and cheerful— I met Mr Josiah S. Johnston, who spoke with commendation of a Methodist preacher he had been hearing named Durbin. I went to Mr Campbell’s Church in the Evening, but there was no preaching there. I came home and finished reading the third Dialogue of Cicero de Oratore. It appears that Cicero himself considered this work as his masterpiece— In the 34th. Section of this dialogue mention is made of Plato as the Instructor of Dion of Syracuse. In Section 35 he thinks ineloquent prudence preferable to loquacious folly. From Section 38. Crassus of elegance of language and metaphorical expressions for the use of which he gives rules and numerous examples— In Section 44. He enters upon the collocation of words, and Oratorical numbers—which he says were first introduced into the discourses of the Greeks by Isocrates— The rule prohibited all combinations of words which would form a verse, yet required that they should be measured for rhythmical harmony— Instead of the dactyl and Spondee he recommends the first and second peon for oratorical numbers The first peon being a long syllable followed by three short ones, and the second three short concluding with one long; and he says that Aristotle recommends the first for the beginning and the last for the close of a Sentence— In a few of the last Sections are comprized all the little elegances which illuminate the discourse concluding with the earnest recommendation of suitable action and the management of the eyes— He relates the Anecdote of Demosthenes attributing the first and second and third power of eloquence to action; confirmed by the Story that Aeschines when in banishment at the Isle of Rhodes, after reading his Oration against Cteriphon, was requested by his hearers to read also the answer of Demosthenes, and upon finding it universally admired, exclaimed, what would you have thought if you had heard the monster himself?
28. IV:15. Monday.

I finished before this morning’s walk the fragment of an Essay, begun the day before Christmas— Mr Gerry paid me a morning visit. He is yet waiting here in suspense— The nominations to Office are not yet sent in Coll. Dwight, introduced judge Betts, District judge of the United States for the Southern District of New-York— Miss Duer came with Mrs Dickinson and Mrs Tayloe, and is daughter of William Duer late a judge of a New-York State Court at Albany, but recently appointed President of Columbia College in the City of New-York— Billing is the Collector of the City taxes, and brought me my City tax-bill for the present year, which I took for examination. Mr Everett spent an hour with me this Evening.— Our Conversation was rather literary than political— He told me that George M’Duffie was person who had prevailed upon Martin of South-Carolina, to decline standing a Candidate for the Speaker’s Chair against A. Stevenson, after he had declared himself a Candidate— Everett told me there was some difficulty in the settlement of his brother Alexander’s Accounts upon some charges for contingencies— He said he had spoken of it to the Secretary of State Van Buren, who told him that he should refer the question to the President, whose inclination was to adhere to the Letter of the Law This as General Pardo used to say was a sottire—for by the Letter of the Law all contingent charges are indefinite, and can only be specified as they arise— Mr Everett told me that Mr Benjamin Vaughan had in two Letters to him requested him to enquire if I had received the packets of manuscripts which he sent me last year— I told him I should write immediately to Mr Vaughan. He marked down the names of most of the writers of the Articles in the last October number of the North-American Review— I read about twenty Sections of Cicero’s Dialogue de Claris Oratoribus, in which Cicero himself is the principal Speaker, in conference with Brutus and Atticus shortly after the death of Hortensius— The introduction to the Treatise is a funeral eulogy upon that Orator, his rival at the Bar and his Colleague in the College of Augurs.
29. V:30. Tuesday.

I made out a list of the manuscript Books and papers which were contained in the Trunk which had belonged to my father— The Books contain nearly all the Letters, public and private written by him while he was President of the United States and are essentially important to complete his correspondence scattered as it is over forty Folio Volumes, at Boston and Quincy. The loose papers in this Trunk are not of much value; excepting a number of Letters from my Mother. and a few from my father to my brother Thomas. a few from him, from my brother Charles and from myself, the perusal of which brought to my mind little else than painful recollections. Upon the Volumes of his own Letters I have not commenced, intending hereafter to read in regular Chronological order, all his Letters that I possess. Nor have I yet commenced upon his old Journals which I brought with me from Quincy— I had Morning visits from Mr Strong a member of the House of Representatives from a District in the State of New-York, and from Mr Seymour the Senator with two young men from his State of Vermont— I received a short and ominous Letter from Petty Vaughan, and wrote one to his father Benjamin Vaughan at Hallowell— I resumed the Paper
upon Parties in the United States which I left unfinished in the Spring, and which I could not bring myself to resume in the Summer at Quincy. It has a tedious aspect at present, and threatens again great prolixity before I can bring it to a close— I am reading an Article by Mr Bowditch upon the history of Astronomy during the last century in the North American Review of April 1825—continued upon Cicero de Claris Oratoribus— He enumerates many Grecian Orators, whose works are no longer extant, but the number of Romans whom he mentions, and of whose Orations he speaks with high commendation is surprizing— The most eloquent of them all he pronounces to be Lucius Crassus and Marcus Antonius the two principal interlocutors of his dialogues de Oratore; and he describes the peculiar Style of Eloquence of each of them. He says they would never be surpassed unless by a Speaker profoundly versed in Philosophy, Jurisprudence, and History—upon which Brutus observes that there is such a person, meaning Cicero himself.
30. IV— Wednesday.

Morning visit from Dr Sewall, who as usual spoke to me about judge Cony and his visit to me last Summer. I returned several visits; leaving Cards— Met Count Menou the Chargé d’Affaires from France at the door of Baron Stackelberg, the Charge d’Affaires from Sweden— A new Minister by the name of Roux de Rochelle, is coming out from France— The only person whom I found at home was Mrs Rush; and while I was there General Mason came in— They have just received Letters from Mr Rush, at London of 24. Novr. announcing his success in obtaining a loan of one Million of Dollars for the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Company—at Amsterdam— He had failed to obtain it in England— And he writes to Mrs Rush that he proposes to embark on his return to this Country the 16th. of this Month— General Mason mentioned Letters received from his Son John, who has been Secretary of Legation to Mr Poinsett in Mexico— The Mexican Government finally demanded the recall of Poinsett which was immediately granted, and Coll. Antony Butler was sent as Chargé d’Affaires to take his place— Mrs Rush spoke about the paragraph in the President’s Message against the Bank, and about Mrs Eaton, wife of the Secretary of War; now the centre of much political intrigue and controversy— Mrs Eaton is the daughter of a man named O’Neal who some years since kept a Tavern and failed so that his house was sold to pay his debts. Mrs Eaton was wife to a purser in the Navy named Timberlake, who being on service in the Mediterranean Squadron, his wife lived at her father’s, where Mr Eaton and General Jackson when a Senator were lodgers. When O’Neal’s house was sold it was purchased by Mr Eaton— About a year and a half since Timberlake died, and very shortly after Eaton married his widow— Her reputation was not in good odour, and last Spring when Eaton was appointed Secretary of War, a grave question arose among the dignitaries high and low of the Administration, whether Mrs Eaton was to associate with their wives— This question has occasioned a schism in the party some of whom have more and some less of moral scruple, the Vice-President’s wife Mrs Calhoun, being of the virtuous, and having then declared that rather than endure the contamination of Mrs Eaton’s company, she would not come to Washington this Winter, and accordingly she remains in the untainted atmosphere of South-Carolina— I told Mrs Rush that this struggle was likely to terminate in a party division of Caps and Hats. Settled my tax-bill with W. W. Billing.
31. V. Thursday.

Mr Van Zandt came, and prevailed upon me to subscribe for the Encyclopaedia Americana, edited by Dr Lieber and E. Wigglesworth tho’ I had declined to subscribe for it when the first volume was brought to me at Quincy last October Mrs Tudor paid us a morning visit and also Coll. Thomas who comes from suttling for the troops at Holten Plantation and who gave me an Account of his intercourse, with the present Secretary of War— He also gave me advice I fear too well founded, but which I cannot yet follow— I finished reading the Treatise of Cicero de Claris Oratoribus, the closing paragraph of which is imperfect, although there seem to be only a few sentences, perhaps only part of one sentence lost. The last eighteen or twenty Sections are among the most interesting of all Cicero’s writings— They are introduced by a sarcastic remark of Atticus, upon the multitudes of Speakers whom Cicero had included in his list of Orators; many of whom Atticus insists were no Orators at all— Atticus laughs at him also, for comparing Cato the Censor, as an Orator with Lysias; but Cicero very seriously maintains the position— He had declined saying anything upon the living Orators, but they prevail upon him to make an exception for himself, who he presents in parallel with Hortensius— The character that he gives of Hortensius is in a strain of lofty Panegyric. He was an Orator of the florid, Asiatic Style— Among his extraordinary talents he mentions his method of dividing his discourses into parts— This same Talent Cicero had noticed in his first Oration for Quinctius and made it the occasion to shew that he himself was master of the same faculty— At the distance of thirty years he celebrates it again; and there is perhaps no more certain test of an accomplished Orator— The Account of Cicero’s preparatory Studies, of his indefatigable labours, and of his first appearance, opposed to Hortensius in a public Cause, the defence of Roscius Amerinus, is an excellent study for a youth of laudable Ambition— It is a rivalship of twenty years, during which they were engaged in an immense number of causes, each as he says preferring the performances of the other to his own—until says Cicero, his voice was extinguished by his own fate, and mine by that of the Public— I shall advert again to these works of Cicero upon Oratory.

Day. I rise usually between 4 and 6. and on the average about 5. Read five Psalms. Write if there remains time till a few minutes past six— Walk round the Capitol Square, day-light dawning as I go; and return just before Sunrise. Read till our breakfast about nine— Allow two hours for that and for reading the Journals of the day— Read, write, receive visitors, and idle away the hours till four in the afternoon— Then dine— Two hours of idleness ensue, and two or three of reading or writing till about ten, when I retire to bed— My writing has been only this diary—a few Letters, and a few pages upon topics of political Speculation— Nothing useful— My reading, the Life of Arthur Lee—Cicero de Oratore and de Claris Oratoribus, and a few Articles of late Reviews— On the whole the Month has been unprofitably and wastefully spent— May the Account of the next be more satisfactory to myself.

At the close of the year the only Sentiment that I feel to be proper is of humble gratitude to God, for the blessings with which it has been favoured— Its chastisements have been most afflictive; but I have experienced Mercy with Judgment— The loss of Power and of popular favour I could have endured with fortitude, and relief from the Slavery of Public Office was more than a compensation for all the privations, incident to the loss of place— Its varieties I despised; and its flatteries never gave me a moment of enjoyment.— But my beloved Son! Mysterious Heaven! let me bow in submission to thy Will— Let me no longer yield to a desponding or distrustful Sprit— Grant me Fortitude— Patience— Perseverance; and active Energy— And let thy Will be done.
